using DataFrames
function generate_data_table(Î»s, Ïƒs, T1s, T2s, source_idx; Ïƒ_lb=1e-25, Ïƒ_ub=1.0, T_lb=290.0, T_ub=305.0, Î»_lb=200.0, Î»_ub=1100.0)
    Tout = [T1s[source_idx[i]] for i âˆˆ 1:size(source_idx, 1)]
    
    # we want T2 to be NaN
    idx = [ i for i  âˆˆ 1:size(source_idx,1) if isnan(T2s[source_idx[i]])]
    Î»out = Î»s[idx]
    Ïƒout = Ïƒs[idx]
    Tout = Tout[idx]
    source_out = source_idx[idx]

    # we want T between T_lb and T_ub
    idx2 = [i for i âˆˆ 1:size(Î»out,1) if (T_lb â‰¤ Tout[i] && Tout[i] â‰¤ T_ub)]
    Î»out = Î»out[idx2]
    Ïƒout = Ïƒout[idx2]
    Tout = Tout[idx2]
    source_out = source_out[idx2]

    # we want Ïƒ to not be NaN and greater than 0.
    idx3 = [i for i âˆˆ 1:size(Ïƒout,1) if !isnan(Ïƒout[i]) && (Ïƒout[i] > Ïƒ_lb) && (Ïƒout[i] â‰¤ Ïƒ_ub)]
    Î»out = Î»out[idx3]
    Ïƒout = Ïƒout[idx3]
    Tout = Tout[idx3]
    source_out = source_out[idx3]

    # we want Î» to be between Î»_lb and Î»_ub
    idx4 = [i for i âˆˆ 1:size(Î»out,1) if (Î»_lb â‰¤ Î»out[i] && Î»out[i] â‰¤ Î»_ub)]
    Î»out = Î»out[idx4]
    Ïƒout = Ïƒout[idx4]
    Tout = Tout[idx4]
    source_out = source_out[idx4]
   
    # idxs = [i for i âˆˆ 1:size(source_idx, 1) if (T_lb < Temps[i] && Temps[i] < T_ub) && (!isnan(Ïƒs[i])) && (Ïƒs[i] â‰¥ 0.0) && (Î»_lb â‰¤ Î»s[i] && Î»s[i] â‰¤ Î»_ub) && isnan(T2s[source_idx[i]])]

    # 5. Create table with data containing the good values
    #data_table = Tables.columntable((; Î»=Î»out, Ïƒ=Ïƒout, T=Tout, source_id=source_out))
    df =  DataFrame(Î»=Î»out, Ïƒ=Ïƒout, T=Tout, source_id=source_out)
    return df
end

We can now thik of this as providing our training data. The goal is to learn a function \(f:(\lambda, T) \mapsto \sigma\). Our model of choice will be to use a gaussian process.

First letâ€™s split up the data into training and testing pairs.

Important

We should think carefully about how to do this. The most important information is probably in regions where there is rapid changes. We can also examine fitting \(\log(\sigma)\) if \(\sigma\) alone is to sharply peakedâ€¦

n = nrow(df)
train_frac = 0.1

idxs = shuffle(1:n)
ntrain = round(Int, (1.0 - train_frac)*n)

idx_train = idxs[1:ntrain]
idx_test = idxs[ntrain+1:end]


df_train = df[idx_train, :]
df_test = df[idx_test, :]

Î»â‚ = minimum(df.Î»)
Î»â‚‚ = maximum(df.Î»)
Tâ‚ = minimum(df.T)
Tâ‚‚ = maximum(df.T)

Î”Î» = Î»â‚‚ - Î»â‚
Î”T = Tâ‚‚ - Tâ‚

fudge_fac = 0.1
Î»â‚ = Î»â‚ - fudge_fac*Î”Î»
Î»â‚‚ = Î»â‚‚ + fudge_fac*Î”Î»
Tâ‚ = Tâ‚ - fudge_fac*Î”T
Tâ‚‚ = Tâ‚‚ + fudge_fac*Î”T

function make_training_data(n, Î½)
    xs = reshape(collect(range(0.0, stop=1.0, length=500)), (1,500))

    y(x) = (exp(-x/(0.5)^2) * sin(2Ï€*Î½*x)) + (0.3)^2*(rand()-0.5)
    ytruth(x) = exp(-x/(0.5)^2) * sin(2Ï€*Î½*x)

    X = Tables.table(rand(1,n)', header=[:x])
    Xtrue = Tables.table(xs', header=[:x])

    y = y.(X.x)
    ytrue = ytruth.(Xtrue.x)

    return X, y, Xtrue, ytrue
end
